message.content:
<<<api>>>: StringTokenizer.nextToken()
<<<code>>>: 
import java.util.Scanner;
import java.util.StringTokenizer;

class TitleApplier {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        String name;
        String[] male = {"Elroy", "Fred", "Graham"};
        String[] females = {"Amy", "Buffy", "Cathy"};
        Scanner scan = new Scanner(System.in);
        
        while(true) {
            System.out.println("Enter a name: ");
            name = scan.nextLine();
            
            if(name.isEmpty()) {
                break;
            }
            
            StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(name);
            String firstName = st.nextToken();
            
            boolean isMale = false;
            boolean isFemale = false;
            
            for(String maleName : male) {
                if(firstName.equals(maleName)) {
                    isMale = true;
                    break;
                }
            }
            
            for(String femaleName : females) {
                if(firstName.equals(femaleName)) {
                    isFemale = true;
                    break;
                }
            }
            
            if(isMale) {
                System.out.println("Mr. " + name);
            } else if(isFemale) {
                System.out.println("Ms. " + name);
            } else {
                System.out.println(name);
            }
        }
    }
}

<<<explanation>>>: 
In this code, we use the StringTokenizer class to split the user's input into separate words. We then check if the first word (assumed to be the first name) matches any of the male or female names. If it does, we add the appropriate title ("Mr." or "Ms.") before printing the full name. If the first name does not match any of the specified names, we simply print the full name without a title. The program continues to prompt for names until the user hits "enter" without typing a name.
